title: FRACTURE Index
description: Predicts 5-year hip fracture risk in postmenopausal women using clinical risk factors with or without bone mineral density measurements.

parameters.name: arms_to_stand
parameters.description: Need to use arms to stand from chair

parameters.name: bmd_t_score
parameters.description: Bone Mineral Density T-score (optional, femoral neck or total hip)

result.name: fracture_risk_score
result.description: Total FRACTURE Index score predicting 5-year hip fracture risk

ranges.interpretation: Score <4 indicates low risk for hip fracture. 5-year hip fracture risk ranges from <0.6% to 2.9%. Continue routine care with lifestyle measures including adequate calcium, vitamin D, weight-bearing exercise, and fall prevention.

ranges.description: Elevated 5-year hip fracture risk requiring evaluation
ranges.interpretation: Score ≥4 (without BMD) or ≥6 (with BMD) suggests further evaluation is warranted. 5-year hip fracture risk ranges from 3.0% to 8.7%. Consider bone density testing, FRAX assessment, and evaluation for osteoporosis treatment based on clinical judgment and guidelines.

references: Black DM, Palermo L, Nevitt MC, et al. Defining incident vertebral deformity: a prospective comparison of several approaches. The Study of Osteoporotic Fractures Research Group. J Bone Miner Res. 1999;14(1):90-101.
Black DM, Steinbuch M, Palermo L, et al. An assessment tool for predicting fracture risk in postmenopausal women. Osteoporos Int. 2001;12(7):519-28.
Cummings SR, Nevitt MC, Browner WS, et al. Risk factors for hip fracture in white women. Study of Osteoporotic Fractures Research Group. N Engl J Med. 1995;332(12):767-73.
Ensrud KE, Lipschutz RC, Cauley JA, et al. Body size and hip fracture risk in older women: a prospective study. Study of Osteoporotic Fractures Research Group. Am J Med. 1997;103(4):274-80.
formula: Sum of weighted risk factors: Age (0-5 points) + Fracture after 50 (0-1 point) + Mother's hip fracture (0-1 point) + Weight <57.7 kg (1 point) + Current smoker (1 point) + Arms to stand (2 points) + BMD T-score (0-4 points, optional)
notes: Developed primarily for White postmenopausal women aged 65 and older
Not recommended for use in men or those with secondary causes of osteoporosis
Can be used with or without bone mineral density measurements
Score ≥4 (without BMD) or ≥6 (with BMD) suggests need for further evaluation
Simple, practical tool for outpatient assessment
Helps identify patients who may benefit from osteoporosis prevention strategies
Should be used in conjunction with clinical judgment and current guidelines
Consider FRAX calculator for more comprehensive fracture risk assessment
Weight threshold of 57.7 kg (127 lbs) used for scoring
BMD T-score can be from femoral neck or total hip measurement
Age scoring: 65-69 (1 point), 70-74 (2 points), 75-79 (3 points), 80-84 (4 points), ≥85 (5 points)
BMD T-score scoring: ≥-1.0 (0 points), -1.1 to -2.0 (1 point), -2.1 to -2.5 (2 points), -2.6 to -3.0 (3 points), <-3.0 (4 points)
